Hi Daniel,

We hope you are well.

The EPP client reads the devices and information from Device Manager and send it to the EPP server. If for example a specific device was connected at one point to a computer with the EPP client installed, and that EPP client communicated to the EPP server then that device will appear on the EPP server, with the last computer seen/connected the one that had the EPP client installed on it. If the device is removed from that computer and connected to another computer which doesn't have the EPP client installed, then it will still appear on the EPP server, but it will only show it as last connected to the computer that had the EPP client installed(which communicated to the EPP server). There will be fields with dates when it was last seen on the EPP client and on the EPP server.

In your example the device will appear on the EPP server, but it will not show you were it is connected now, it will only show you that X time ago it was connected to a computer that had the EPP client installed and it communicated with the EPP server.

Please let me know if this answered your question.

Best Regards,

The EPP client reads the devices and information from Device Manager and send it to the EPP server. If for example a specific device was connected at one point to a computer with the EPP client installed, and that EPP client communicated to the EPP server then that device will appear on the EPP server, with the last computer seen/connected the one that had the EPP client installed on it. If the device is removed from that computer and connected to another computer which doesn't have the EPP client installed, then it will still appear on the EPP server, but it will only show it as last connected to the computer that had the EPP client installed(which communicated to the EPP server). There will be fields with dates when it was last seen on the EPP client and on the EPP server.

In your example the device will appear on the EPP server, but it will not show you were it is connected now, it will only show you that X time ago it was connected to a computer that had the EPP client installed and it communicated with the EPP server.

The EPP client reads the devices and information from Device Manager and send it to the EPP server. In your example the device will appear on the EPP server, but it will not show you were it is connected now, it will only show you that X time ago it was connected to a computer that had the EPP client installed and it communicated with the EPP server.

After the eDiscovery scan finished and it returned the items that you were scanning for, it gives you those options:
1. Encrypt on target - encrypt that file on the end users computer.

The EPP client reads the devices and information from Device Manager and send it to the EPP server. If for example a specific device was connected at one point to a computer with the EPP client installed, and that EPP client communicated to the EPP server then that device will appear on the EPP server, with the last computer seen/connected the one that had the EPP client installed on it. If the device is removed from that computer and connected to another computer which doesn't have the EPP client installed, then it will still appear on the EPP server, but it will only show it as last connected to the computer that had the EPP client installed(which communicated to the EPP server). There will be fields with dates when it was last seen on the EPP client and on the EPP server.

In your example the device will appear on the EPP server, but it will not show you were it is connected now, it will only show you that X time ago it was connected to a computer that had the EPP client installed and it communicated with the EPP server.
